message.content: Search the web for "Premiere Pro UXP createSetNameAction execute" or "ppro.Constants action execute". The clip.createSetNameAction(label) method exists but calling .execute() on it fails with "Script action failed to execute". How do you properly execute actions created by createSetNameAction in UXP?

content.content:
Web search results for query: "Premiere Pro UXP createSetNameAction execute "Script action failed to execute""

Links: [{"title":"Help with the new UXP createInsertProjectItemAction() method. \"Script Action failed to execute\"","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/help-with-the-new-uxp-createinsertprojectitemaction-method-quot-script-action-failed-to-execute-quot/m-p/15239302"}]

Based on my search results, I found relevant information about the "Script Action failed to execute" error in Premiere Pro UXP, though it's specifically about `createInsertProjectItemAction` rather than `createSetNameAction`. The issue and solution appear to be similar for these action methods.

## Premiere Pro UXP "Script Action failed to execute" Error

Users have been trying to use UXP action methods like `createInsertProjectItemAction()` to work with Premiere Pro's timeline, but encounter the error "Script Action failed to execute."

### Key Solution

The solution involves using `lockedAccess` and `executeTransaction` - these methods did the trick for users experiencing this issue. This applies to various action methods including `createAddMarkerAction` and likely `createSetNameAction` as well.

Users were following the documentation correctly in terms of setting up the function itself, but needed additional context from the sample panel.

### Additional Tips

If using the sample panel from GitHub, `npm run fix-imports` needs to be run to correct some errors that result from the current build process.(no content)For the provided 3psample-panel, npm is used and the TypeScript compiler is not needed.

### Summary

The "Script Action failed to execute" error typically occurs when the action methods aren't wrapped properly in `lockedAccess` and `executeTransaction` calls. Make sure your code structure follows this pattern rather than calling the action methods directly.

Would you like me to search for more specific information about `createSetNameAction` or the proper usage pattern for these action methods?


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on my search results, here's what I found about Premiere Pro UXP API, action execution, and ppro.Constants in 2025:

## Premiere Pro UXP API Overview

UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere Pro and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level.(no content)As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP. ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

## Using ppro.Constants

To use any constant, import the constants object from the Premiere module first.

Here's an example of using constants in the UXP API:
To access trackItems inside of caption track and use available trackItem API, you will need input parameters: trackItemType and includeEmptyTrackItem for getTrackItems API. An example usage would be like `const trackItems = await captionTrack.getTrackItems(ppro.Constants.TrackItemType.CLIP, ...`

## Action Execution Issues

Users have been trying to use the new UXP createInsertProjectItemAction() method to insert clips into sequences, but some encounter the error "Script Action failed to execute."(no content)The solution involves using `lockedAccess` and `executeTransaction` - these did the trick for users experiencing this issue.

## API Method Types

Actions in the API work by returning action objects, such as `createSetInPointAction(tickTime: TickTime): Action` which returns an action that sets the in point of the Project item.(no content)An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, which blocked the Premiere UI while executing. In UXP, a method call is asynchronous and does not block the UI thread.

## Current Status

As of August 2025, only Premiere Pro BETA builds support UXP plugins. The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

## Premiere Pro UXP API Overview

It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level.(no content)As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP. ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

## Using ppro.Constants

To use any constant, import the constants object from the Premiere module first.

Here's an example of using constants in the UXP API:
To access trackItems inside of caption track and use available trackItem API, you will need input parameters: trackItemType and includeEmptyTrackItem for getTrackItems API. An example usage would be like `const trackItems = await captionTrack.getTrackItems(ppro.Constants.TrackItemType.CLIP, ...`

input.prompt: Extract the full code examples showing how to use Action objects in Premiere Pro UXP, especially createSetNameAction or similar naming/labeling actions. Show the complete pattern for executing actions.

Find any sample code showing how to execute actions like createSetNameAction, createSetLabelAction, or any clip modification actions. Look for examples using lockedAccess and executeTransaction with compoundAction.addAction().

content.content:
# UXP Premiere Pro Sample Code Search

Based on the provided GitHub repository content, **I cannot locate sample code demonstrating the specific actions you're seeking** (createSetNameAction, createSetLabelAction, clip modification actions, lockedAccess, executeTransaction, or compoundAction.addAction()).

## What's Available

The repository contains:
- A sample UXP plugin panel for Premiere Pro
- Build instructions using `npm i` and `npm run build`
- TypeScript definitions for development in Visual Studio Code
- A transcript JSON definition file

## Recommendation

To find these specific API examples, you should:

1. **Visit the official Premiere Pro UXP documentation** at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ (referenced in the README)
2. **Explore the sample-panels directory** directly in the repository—the actual code files weren't included in this webpage content extract
3. **Check the payloads directory** for additional resources

The repository appears to be a template/starting point rather than a comprehensive API reference with all action examples implemented.

input.prompt: Find the documentation for createSetNameAction and any other action methods on VideoClipTrackItem. Show the method signatures and any usage examples.
Find the type definitions for createSetNameAction, Action, CompoundAction, and any related methods. Show how actions are supposed to be created and executed.

content.content:
# Action Type Definitions in UXP Premiere Pro

## Core Action Types

**Action** is defined as an empty type in the type definitions:
```typescript
export declare type Action = {}
```

**CompoundAction** provides methods for batching multiple actions:
```typescript
export declare type CompoundAction = {
  addAction(action: Action): boolean
  empty: boolean
}
```

## Creating Actions via createSetNameAction

Many objects implement `createSetNameAction` methods that return Action instances. For example:

- **ProjectItem**: `"createSetNameAction(inName: string): Action"` – produces an action renaming a project item
- **ClipProjectItem**: Same signature for renaming clip media
- **FolderItem**: Renames a bin/folder

## Action Execution Pattern

Actions are executed through the `executeTransaction` method on Project objects:

```
executeTransaction(callback: (compoundAction: CompoundAction) => void, 
                   undoString?: string): boolean
```

This pattern allows bundling multiple actions within a single undoable operation. The callback receives a CompoundAction instance where individual actions can be appended using `addAction()`.

## Key Principle

Actions represent deferred operations rather than immediate changes. They're created by helper methods and executed later through transaction mechanisms, enabling undo/redo functionality.

toolUseResult.result:
# Action Type Definitions in UXP Premiere Pro

## Core Action Types

**Action** is defined as an empty type in the type definitions:
```typescript
export declare type Action = {}
```

**CompoundAction** provides methods for batching multiple actions:
```typescript
export declare type CompoundAction = {
  addAction(action: Action): boolean
  empty: boolean
}
```

## Creating Actions via createSetNameAction

Many objects implement `createSetNameAction` methods that return Action instances. For example:

- **ProjectItem**: `"createSetNameAction(inName: string): Action"` – produces an action renaming a project item
- **ClipProjectItem**: Same signature for renaming clip media
- **FolderItem**: Renames a bin/folder

## Action Execution Pattern

Actions are executed through the `executeTransaction` method on Project objects:

```
executeTransaction(callback: (compoundAction: CompoundAction) => void, 
                   undoString?: string): boolean
```

This pattern allows bundling multiple actions within a single undoable operation. The callback receives a CompoundAction instance where individual actions can be appended using `addAction()`.

## Key Principle

Actions represent deferred operations rather than immediate changes. They're created by helper methods and executed later through transaction mechanisms, enabling undo/redo functionality.

content.content:
Web search results for query: ""createSetNameAction" "TrackItem" Premiere Pro UXP site:developer.adobe.com OR site:github.com"

Links: [{"title":"uxp-premiere-pro/src/pages/ppro_reference/types.d.ts at main · AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro","url":"https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro/blob/main/src/pages/ppro_reference/types.d.ts"}]

Based on the search results, I found information about `createSetNameAction` for `TrackItem` in Premiere Pro UXP.

## Results for `createSetNameAction` and `TrackItem` in Premiere Pro UXP

The search found documentation in the Adobe UXP Premiere Pro GitHub repository. Here's what I found:

### `createSetNameAction` Method

The `createSetNameAction(inName: string): Action` method returns an action that renames the trackItem. This is part of the TrackItem interface in the Premiere Pro UXP API.

### Related TrackItem Methods

The TrackItem interface includes several related methods:

- `createSetDisabledAction(disabled: boolean): Action` - Returns an action that enables/disables the trackItem
- `getMediaType(): Promise<Guid>` - Returns UUID representing the underlying media type of this track item
- `getTrackIndex(): Promise<number>` - Index representing the track index of the track this track item belongs to
- `getProjectItem(): Promise<ProjectItem>` - Returns the project item for this track item

### Component Chain Methods

For audio track items, you can use `getComponentChain(): Promise<AudioComponentChain>` which returns an AudioComponentChain.(no content)For video track items, you can use `getComponentChain(): Promise<VideoComponentChain>` which returns a VideoComponentChain.

### Source

The TypeScript definitions are available at: [AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro on GitHub](https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro/blob/main/src/pages/ppro_reference/types.d.ts)


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.
